title: Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma in a Young Patient
setup_script: A 25-year-old man with family history of MEN 2 presents for evaluation of a thyroid nodule. Calcitonin is elevated. Genetic testing confirms a RET mutation. Ultrasound shows a 1.8 cm hypoechoic nodule without nodal enlargement.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Review the significance of elevated calcitonin and RET mutation in medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC).
Discuss need for evaluation of pheochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism as part of MEN 2 workup (measure catecholamines and calcium/PTH).
Order ultrasound of neck and CT if suspicion for nodal metastasis; consider calcitonin doubling time for prognosis.
Counsel patient on recommended prophylactic or therapeutic total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection.
Explain surgical differences from papillary thyroid carcinoma (no radioiodine uptake, reliance on calcitonin markers).
Discuss perioperative considerations: laryngeal nerve monitoring, preservation of parathyroids, management of potential pheochromocytoma.
Perform total thyroidectomy and central compartment lymphadenectomy; excise suspicious lateral nodes if present.
Send tumor and lymph nodes for pathology; record number of positive nodes and margins.
Monitor postoperative calcium and vocal cord function; start calcitonin and CEA follow-up schedule.
Refer patient for genetic counseling and screen family members for RET mutation.
Discuss need for lifelong surveillance with calcitonin and CEA levels and periodic neck imaging.
Address psychosocial impact of hereditary cancer diagnosis and provide support resources.

critical_decision_points: Comprehensive MEN 2 evaluation before thyroid surgery.
Appropriate extent of surgery for MTC including central neck dissection.
Avoidance of inadequate therapy since MTC does not respond to radioiodine.
Postoperative monitoring of calcitonin for recurrence and surveillance.

rubric.resident_feedback_template: This case tested your understanding of hereditary medullary thyroid carcinoma and MEN 2. You should have ordered appropriate genetic testing, evaluated for associated endocrinopathies, and planned a comprehensive thyroidectomy with node dissection. Reflect on your communication regarding hereditary risk and family counseling.
